Abstract: This paper serves as a foundational guide to the field of sociology, tailored for beginners seeking to understand the complexities of human societies. It delves into the history of sociology, tracing its origins from the Enlightenment period to its establishment as a distinct academic discipline in the 19th century. The work highlights key figures such as Auguste Comte, Karl Marx, and Max Weber, whose theories have profoundly influenced sociological thought. Furthermore, it explores sociological pedagogy, offering insights into effective teaching strategies and learning methodologies that facilitate a deeper comprehension of sociological concepts. By integrating theoretical knowledge with practical applications, this paper aims to equip novices with the essential tools to critically analyze social structures, relationships, and dynamics. It is an invaluable resource for educators and students alike, fostering a comprehensive understanding of sociology's role in interpreting and shaping the social world.
